TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit LoginStatus extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.CompositeControl

Docs.summary: Detects the user's authentication state and toggles the state of a link to log in to or log out of a Web site.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax) ## Introduction The control has two states, logged in to the Web site and logged out of the Web site, determined by the property of the object's property. The control displays either a text or an image link, depending on the setting of the and properties. You can display either text or images for one or both states. > [!NOTE] > If you are not familiar with the set of login controls available in ASP.NET, see [ASP.NET Login Controls Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ac032230-6469-4b03-b68d-03ef2643a24d(v=vs.100)) before continuing. For a list of other topics related to login controls and membership, see [Managing Users by Using Membership](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/824c3a24-f0af-427c-a652-0d2d1e9397cd). When a user is not logged in to the site, the control provides a link to the login page defined in the application configuration settings. When the user is logged in to the Web site, the control provides a link to log out of the Web site. Logging out of the Web site clears the user's authentication status and when using cookies will clear the cookie from the user's client computer. On any subsequent visit to the Web site, the control will display the prompt to log in. The logout behavior is controlled by the property, which specifies whether to refresh the current page, redirect the user to the login page defined in the application configuration settings, or redirect the user to a page specified by the property. The default is to refresh the current page. > [!NOTE] > When a user uses the control to log out of a Web site, all data present in view state and all post data is lost. ## Declarative Syntax ``` ```

remarks.format:
## Remarks This member is used primarily by control developers when deriving a custom control from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> class.
This method is called by the ASP.NET infrastructure to notify any controls that use composition-based implementation, including controls that derive from <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CompositeDataBoundControl> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CompositeControl>, to create any child controls they contain in preparation for postback or rendering.

MemberSignature.Value: public event EventHandler LoggedOut;
.event class System.EventHandler LoggedOut
Public Custom Event LoggedOut As EventHandler
public: event EventHandler ^ LoggedOut;
member this.LoggedOut : EventHandler

Docs.summary: Raised after the user clicks the logout link and the logout process is complete.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event is raised on the server after the user clicks the logout link and the logout process is complete.
When the user clicks the logout link, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event is raised, then the logout process is run, and finally the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event is raised.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event to provide additional processing such as cleaning up database connections or removing per-user cached data after the user logs out of a Web site. The user's identity is still available while the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event is executing. If your handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event redirects the client browser to another page, the authentication cookie will be cleared from the client.
## Examples The following code example attaches an event handler to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event. The event handler in this example is empty.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusAfterLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusAfterLogout/CS/loginstatusafterlogoutcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusAfterLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusAfterLogout/VB/loginstatusafterlogoutvb.aspx#1)]

member this.LoggingOut : System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginCancelEventHandler

Docs.summary: Raised when the user clicks the logout button.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event is raised on the server when the user clicks the logout link. The logout process does not occur until after this event, and user information is still available.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event allows you to cancel the logout process if the user must complete an activity before leaving the Web site, such as purchasing items in a shopping cart or submitting changes to a database. You can cancel the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event by setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginCancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginCancelEventArgs> parameter to `true`.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event to provide additional processing, such as clearing per-user data, before a user logs out of a site.
## Examples The following code example attaches an event handler to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event. The event handler updates a field on the form, and then cancels the logout attempt.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusBeforeLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusBeforeLogout/CS/loginstatusbeforelogoutcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusBeforeLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusBeforeLogout/VB/loginstatusbeforelogoutvb.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL of the image used for the login link.
Docs.value: A string containing the URL of the image used for the login link. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> property contains the location of the image used for the login link. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property is used as the alternative text for the image.
If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> is empty, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property is rendered as the link.
## Examples The following code example shows how to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> property to a specific image.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusLoginImageUrl#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLoginImageUrl/CS/loginstatusloginimageurlcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusLoginImageUrl#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLoginImageUrl/VB/loginstatusloginimageurlvb.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text used for the login link.
Docs.value: A string displayed as the login link. The default is "Login".

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property is displayed as the link text when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> property is empty.
When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> property contains a link, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property is used as the alternative text for the image.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
## Examples The following code example shows how to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusLoginText#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLoginText/CS/loginstatuslogintextcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusLoginText#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLoginText/VB/loginstatuslogintextvb.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines the action taken when a user logs out of a Web site with the control.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> property determines which page is presented to the user when he or she logs out using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control.
The following table describes the actions taken for each <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction> value.
|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> value|Action taken| |-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.Redirect>|Redirects the user to the URL contained in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutPageUrl%2A> property. If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutPageUrl%2A> is empty, the user is redirected to the login page defined in the application configuration settings.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.RedirectToLoginPage>|Redirects the user to the login page defined in the application configuration settings.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.Refresh>|Refreshes the current page.|
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes. For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
## Examples The following code example sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> property to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.RedirectToLoginPage> value to send the user to the login page.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusLogoutAction#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutAction/CS/loginstatuslogoutactioncs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusLogoutAction#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutAction/VB/loginstatuslogoutactionvb.aspx#1)]

Docs.exception: The property is set to an invalid value.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutImageUrl%2A> is empty, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> property is rendered as the link.
## Examples The following code example sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutImageUrl%2A> property to a specific image.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL of the logout page.
Docs.value: A string containing the URL of the logout page. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.Redirect>, the user is redirected to the URL contained in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutPageUrl%2A>.
If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> is set to any other value, the contents of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutPageUrl%2A> property are ignored.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes. For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
## Examples The following code example sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutPageUrl%2A> property to a logout page and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutAction%2A> property to <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LogoutAction.Redirect> so that the user is redirected when logging out.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusLogoutPageUrl#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutPageUrl/CS/loginstatuslogoutpageurlcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusLogoutPageUrl#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutPageUrl/VB/loginstatuslogoutpageurlvb.aspx#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> property is displayed when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutImageUrl%2A> property is empty.
When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutImageUrl%2A> property contains a link, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> property is used as the alternative text for the image in browsers that do not support images.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
## Examples The following code example shows how to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> property.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusLogoutText#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutText/CS/loginstatuslogouttextcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusLogoutText#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusLogoutText/VB/loginstatuslogouttextvb.aspx#1)]

Docs.param: An that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Raises the event after the user clicks the logout link and logout processing is complete.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggedOut> event to provide additional processing, such as closing database connections or cleaning up per-user cached data, after the user has logged out of a Web site.
For more information about how to handle events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md). Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnLoggedOut%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
## Examples The following code example attaches an event handler to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnLoggedOut%2A> event. The event handler in this example is empty.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusAfterLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusAfterLogout/CS/loginstatusafterlogoutcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusAfterLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusAfterLogout/VB/loginstatusafterlogoutvb.aspx#1)]

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

Docs.summary: Raises the event when a user clicks the logout link on the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoggingOut> event to provide additional processing, such as cleaning up per-user data, before a user logs out of a site. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnLoggingOut%2A> event can be canceled, so you can give the user the option of saving data such as a shopping cart or database changes before leaving the Web site.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnLoggingOut%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
## Examples The following code example attaches an event handler to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnLoggingOut%2A> event. The event handler updates a field on the form, and then cancels the logout attempt.
[!code-aspx-csharp[LoginStatusBeforeLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusBeforeLogout/CS/loginstatusbeforelogoutcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[LoginStatusBeforeLogout#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginStatusBeforeLogout/VB/loginstatusbeforelogoutvb.aspx#1)]

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: protected internal override void OnPreRender (EventArgs e);
.method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance void OnPreRender(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed

protected public: override void OnPreRender(EventArgs ^ e);
override this.OnPreRender : EventArgs -> unit

Docs.summary: Determines whether a user is logged in, and gets the URL of the login page.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnPreRender%2A> method determines whether the user is logged in by examining the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.IsAuthenticated%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page> object's <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.Request%2A> property. If the user is logged in, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutImageUrl%2A> property is used to render the control. If the user is not logged in, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginImageUrl%2A> property is used to render the control.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.OnPreRender%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.TagKey%2A> property allows the output stream to write the appropriate HTML markup for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.TagKey%2A> property is used primarily by control developers.

block.para: You can override this property to specify which value to use for your derived control.
